intro: Passerina longiflora, commonly known as the long-flowered pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of North America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often vibrant flowers. The plant produces showy, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in early spring, often before the leaves fully emerge. Passerina longiflora is characterized by its slender, erect stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to cold, alpine environments.
